data.title: decal road 'z-fighting'
data.body:
Two decal roads in the same space interpenetrating cause rendering artifacts similar to z-fighting. 

Suggested approach would be to leverage or revise an equivalent of https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/69838bdc8c9bc055b9b1ae76f42b0f28d2a33909/Engine/source/renderInstance/renderPassManager.h#L264 to fix them into a given render-order.

data.title: TSMesh parentMesh ignored when creating VBOs
data.body:
When creating VBO objects, the "parentMesh" property on TSMesh is ignored. This means that even if a model has mesh data shared with other meshes, it will create a distinct VBO for every single mesh. This may affect performance where a model has many meshes, as a VBO switch is needed to render each mesh.

Ideally TSMesh::_createVBIB needs to check if a vertex buffer has parentMesh set, reusing or deferring VBO creation to that mesh. Skinned meshes may also benefit from this, though moreso if Hardware Skinning was implemented.

data.body: This allows designers to set the start and end distance for Alpha LOD on objects.

data.title: Client side Far Clipping adjuster, Client side scene culling and fixing the hitch when players zoom out after loading in.
data.body:
I couldn't create separate pulls due to the way these features are inter-dependant.

First, I've added Far Clipping Client culling to the scene.  In my benchmarks it increases framerate by 5-10 fps in heavily populated zones.
I've added a new global TorqueScript Variable $pref::Camera::FarDistance to allow easy setting and getting of the clipping distance.
I also added it to the Options Dialog for in game use.
The max value the Far Clipping Distance can be is the max Viewable distance defined in the mission.

With this patch, I've also included a fix for the hitching for when players zoom out for the first time or when they enter a heavily populated area.
The idea is to load all LOD's of all Shapebase and Static objects into the video card before the first render.  This removes the hitch players
see when they scroll out after loading into the game.

data.body:
By default it is not included in the build, you must #define GHOSTSCOPING in the torqueConfig.h to enable it.
The distance can be set via the mission file by adding

visibleGhostDistance = "1000";

Or if it is not set in the mission file it will default to what is defined in torqueConfig.h #defined as GHOSTSCOPING_DEFAULT_DISTANCE_IF_NOT_IN_MISSION

The mission default distance can be overridden on a per connection basis by using gameconnection:setVisibleGhostDistance and gameconnection:getVisibleGhostDistance

The logic for setting the scoping distance was moved from shapebase in the original design to SceneObject so that it will affect cameras, players, etc.

data.body:
... might make someone

think that it's not working right.  So what I did was determine if the camera is inside the sphere.
If the camera is inside the sphere, then I find the distance from the center of the sphere to the camera
Round down and use that as the radius to draw the sphere.
That way if someone zooms in or out, their screen is still showing the sphere.
